The term 'extrasynaptic' refers to the release of these neuropeptides outside of the synaptic cleft, which is the small gap between the presynaptic and postsynaptic neurons. This means that the neuropeptides can act on receptors located on the surface of the postsynaptic neuron, but not within the synaptic cleft. This mechanism can enhance or modulate the transmission of signals between neurons.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where is serotonin present in the GIT ?: Serotonin is present in the myenteric plexus of the GIT.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which waves out of alpha and delta waves: The waves with the largest amplitude are the delta waves.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which cranial nerves have both afferent: The cranial nerves that have both afferent and efferent branches are the Trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) and the Trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where does the ventral tegmental area pr: The ventral tegmental area projects to the nucleus accumbens.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the purpose of the outer hair ce: The outer hair cells are concerned with amplification of sound.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the hypothalamus: The hypothalamus is a part of the brain that controls many important functions in the body, including regulating body temperature, hunger, thirst, and sleep. It also helps to control hormone production in the pituitary gland.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are antagonists for GABAb receptors: The antagonists for GABAb receptors are Saclofen and CGP 56911A.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where does the cerebral aqueduct open in: The cerebral aqueduct opens into the 3rd ventricle at the level of the superior colliculus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the different families of neuro: The different families of neuropeptides include the enkephalins, endorphins, and angiotensin II.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens when the stereocillia move: When the stereocillia move towards the kinacillium, it results in the opening of mechanically gated ion channels.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What 2nd messenger system does dopamine: Dopamine uses the 2nd messenger system of Cyclic AMP (cAMP).
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is a major subcortical input to are: The major subcortical input to area 6 is the substantia nigra.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What can be seen on the dorsal surface o: On the dorsal surface of the brainstem, one can see the inferior colliculi and the superior colliculi.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What structures make up the basal gangli: The basal ganglia are made up of the striatum and the pallidum.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are heteroreceptors?: Heteroreceptors are receptors that respond to more than one type of chemical signal.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What tracts are present in the antero-la: The tracts present in the antero-lateral regions of the White matter are the Cerebrospinal tract and the Rubrospinal tract.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Why do higher levels of the spinal cord: Higher levels of the spinal cord contain more white matter because the axons from the body's periphery converge on the spinal cord and then project to the brain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens to neuropeptides after ther: Neuropeptides are reabsorbed into the presynaptic neuron after their release.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is substance P ?: Substance P is a neuropeptide that is released from nerve endings in response to painful stimuli. It is involved in the transmission of pain signals in the body.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are opioids involved in ?: Opioids are involved in the transmission of pain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which regions of the cross section of th: The regions of the cross section of the spinal cord that have a larger ventral horn are the cervical and lumbar regions.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where is Broca\u2019s area ?: Broca’s area is located in the posterior part of the left inferior frontal gyrus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which laminae do each of the afferent fi: Each afferent fibre terminates in one lamina.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the later symptoms of ad ?: The later symptoms of ad include the inability to walk, incontinence, and mental deterioration.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How are cholinergic neurons identified ?: Cholinergic neurons are identified by the presence of acetylcholine (Ach) in their synaptic vesicles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what the process that occurs when the he: The process that occurs when the head angle changes or accelerates is called nystagmus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Explain the structure of NMDA receptors: NMDA receptors are a type of glutamate receptor that is ionotropic, meaning they form an ion channel pore. They are heterotetrameric, consisting of four subunits, which can be either NR1, NR2A, NR2B, or NR3A. The NR1 subunit is essential for the channel's function, while the NR2 and NR3 subunits determine the receptor's properties. The structure of NMDA receptors is crucial for their role in synaptic plasticity and neuronal excitability.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How many alpha subunits have to be prese: 5 alpha subunits are required for the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor to be functional because the receptor is a pentamer, meaning it has 5 subunits.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the red nucleus: The red nucleus is part of the midbrain and is involved in the regulation of motor movements.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.In the spinal cord where are you most li: Large neuronal cell bodies are most likely to be found in the thoracic region of the spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.explain pacinian\u2019s corpuscles?: Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings that are responsible for the sensation of touch. They are located in the skin, particularly in the dermal papillae, and are named after the Italian physician who first described them, Giorgio Pacini. These corpuscles are encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, which allows them to detect mechanical stimuli such as pressure and vibration. When stimulated, they send signals through the dorsal root ganglia to the brain, allowing us to perceive touch sensations.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens to on centre bipolar cells: When the centre is in the dark, on centre bipolar cells stop transmitting signals to the ganglion cell.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the flexor reflex ?: The flexor reflex is a withdrawal reflex that helps to protect the body from harm. When a painful stimulus is applied to the skin, the muscles closest to the stimulus contract to pull the limb away from the source of pain. This reflex is an example of a monosynaptic reflex.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is neuropeptide y ?: Neuropeptide Y is a peptide that is found in the brain and is involved in various physiological processes, including appetite regulation, stress response, and energy expenditure.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are neurohormones ?: Neurohormones are hormones that are secreted by the neurosecretory cells of the neurohypophysis and the paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus. They are released into the bloodstream and transported to their target tissues where they exert their effects.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are taste buds like ?: Taste buds are like small, pinkish-white bumps on the tongue and the inside of the mouth.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Why is colour blindness more common in m: Colour blindness is more common in men than women because the genes responsible for colour vision are located on the X chromosome. Men have one X and one Y chromosome, so if they inherit an X chromosome with a faulty gene for colour vision, they will express the condition. Women, on the other hand, have two X chromosomes, so even if one X chromosome has the faulty gene, the other can compensate, reducing the likelihood of expressing colour blindness.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the small core of the mesencepha: The small core of the mesencephalon is the pretectum.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what cells of the cerebellar cortex are: Purkinje cells of the cerebellar cortex are excitatory.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What does the hindbrain include ?: The hindbrain includes the cerebellum and the brainstem.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the 3 main forces that affect b: The 3 main forces that affect blood flow through the lungs are: 1) the pressure difference between the pulmonary artery and the pulmonary veins, 2) the resistance in the pulmonary vessels, and 3) the lung compliance, which refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and contract.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What do alpha motor neurons innervate ?: Alpha motor neurons innervate multi-joint muscles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the most common neurodegenerativ: Alzheimer's disease is the most common neurodegenerative disorder.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens to the succinic semialdehyd: The succinic semialdehyde is then converted to succinic acid.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the steps the follow activation: The steps that follow activation of a metabotropic receptor include: 1. Activation of G-protein 2. Activation of second messenger 3. Activation of second messenger 4. Activation of second messenger 5. Activation of second messenger.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What does hemiplegia mean ?: Hemiplegia is a condition characterized by the paralysis of one side of the body.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the helicotrema ?: The helicotrema is the space between the basilar membrane and the stria vascularis of the cochlea.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What effects occur when GABAb is stimula: Stimulation of GABAb receptors produces sedation and muscle relaxation.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the concentration of ions in th: The concentration of ions in the endolymph is 140mM.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the similarities of chemical an: Both chemical and electrical signals involve the use of a synapse to transmit information.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are mGluR1s mostly located and whe: mGluR1s are mostly located in the cerebellum, while mGluR2+3s are mostly located in the hippocampus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is fast pain ?: Fast pain is a type of pain that is quickly sensed by the body and is typically associated with tissue damage. It is often described as a sharp or prickly sensation and is usually of short duration.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Describe slow motor units: Slow motor units are characterized by their low frequency of action potentials, which means they contract at a slower rate. They are often found in muscles that require precise and sustained contractions, such as those involved in posture or equilibrium. These motor units are type I fibers and are known for their red color and high mitochondrial content, which provides them with a rich oxygen supply and allows them to generate ATP through aerobic metabolism. This enables them to contract for extended periods without fatigue.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens in the zone of lissauer and: In the zone of lissauer, there is a high concentration of red blood cells. This can affect the blood's ability to carry oxygen and may lead to symptoms such as fatigue and shortness of breath.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the effects of wernickes aphasi: Wernickes aphasias effects include fluent but nonsensical speech, difficulty in comprehension, and impaired repetition.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the cerebellum a: The cerebellum and primary motor area work together to produce voluntary movements. The cerebellum is responsible for planning and timing the movements, while the primary motor area sends the actual motor commands to the muscles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is phase locking ?: Phase locking refers to the process of synchronizing the firing of action potentials in neurons with the same or similar frequencies.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What tracts are present in the posterior: The posterior funiculus contains the fasciculus gracilis and the fasciculus cuneatus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.When an action potential occurs why does: When an action potential occurs, the membrane potential does not reach the equilibrium potential of sodium because the sodium-potassium pump is not able to keep up with the rapid influx of sodium ions into the cell. This is due to the fact that the pump can only move a certain number of ions per unit of time, and during an action potential, the influx of sodium ions is too fast for the pump to counteract. As a result, the membrane potential remains positive and does not return to the equilibrium potential of sodium.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is hyperalgesia ?: Hyperalgesia is a condition where there is an increased sensitivity to pain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.The red nucleus is a motor nucleus assoc: The red nucleus is a motor nucleus associated with the midbrain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How do mGluR2s work at presynaptic neuro: mGluR2s are metabotropic glutamate receptors that, when activated by glutamate, lead to the closure of voltage-gated calcium channels. This action reduces the influx of calcium ions into the neuron, thereby inhibiting neurotransmitter release.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What extra molecule does glutamate have: Glutamate has an extra carboxyl group compared to aspartate.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What did staining with cytochrome oxidas: Staining with cytochrome oxidase in the cortex revealed the presence of a dark blue color in the outer layers of the cerebral cortex, indicating the activity of cytochrome oxidase, which is an enzyme involved in the electron transport chain and is used as a marker for oxidative phosphorylation.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How are olfactory receptors distributed: Olfactory receptors are distributed uniformly across the olfactory epithelium.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is contra lateral neglect syndrome: Contra lateral neglect syndrome is a condition where a patient ignores or fails to attend to stimuli on the side of space opposite to the side of the brain lesion.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Describe the anterior nuclear group of t: The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus nuclei consists of the anterodorsal nucleus and the anteroventral nucleus. These nuclei are part of the thalamus, which is a collection of nuclei located in the brain and involved in various functions, including sensory and motor signal relay, and playing a role in the regulation of consciousness and alertness.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the optic disk ?: The optic disk is the point where the optic nerve enters the eyeball.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the interthalamic adhesion and w: The interthalamic adhesion is a structure located in the third ventricle of the brain. It is a thin fold of pia mater that extends across the third ventricle, connecting the two thalamic bodies.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are the cell bodies are sympatheti: The cell bodies of sympathetic post ganglionic neurons are found in the ganglia.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What do the neurons of m1 encode ?: The neurons of m1 encode the force of contraction.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the pathway for functional hiera: The functional hierarchy of motor systems is as follows: commands from the cerebral cortex are sent to the cerebellum, which then sends signals to the brain stem. The brain stem then communicates with the spinal cord, which in turn controls the muscles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens when glycine and NMDA bind: When glycine and NMDA bind to NMDA receptors, it leads to the opening of the receptor's ion channel, allowing the influx of calcium ions into the neuron.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what are the 2 main structures of the ve: The two main structures of the vestibular labyrinth are the semicircular canals and the otolith organs.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the transduction cascade for bit: The transduction cascade for bitter tastants involves the T1R2 and T1R3 taste receptors, which are expressed in different regions of the tongue. When these receptors are activated by bitter substances, they lead to the inhibition of adenylyl cyclase via G-protein coupled receptors. This inhibition results in a decrease in the production of cyclic AMP (cAMP), which in turn reduces the activity of the sodium channel. As a result, there is a decrease in sodium influx, leading to a decrease in cell depolarization and ultimately a decrease in neural firing, which is perceived as the sensation of bitterness.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the symptoms of motor neurons d: The symptoms of motor neurons disease include muscle weakness, difficulty speaking and swallowing, muscle stiffness, and muscle twitching.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the functions of the medial hyp: The medial hypothalamus contains several nuclei that perform various functions. These include the regulation of thirst, hunger, sleep-wake cycles, and the production of hormones that control the release of gonadotropins from the pituitary gland.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What 2nd messenger system does glutamate: Glutamate class 2 receptors use the 2nd messenger system of IP3/DAG.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens with noradrenaline binds to: When noradrenaline binds to a beta-adrenergic receptor, it causes bronchodilation.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is teh predatory aggression pathway: The predatory aggression pathway is the hypothalamic pathway that is involved in the control of predatory behavior.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the BRAINSTEM ?: The BRAINSTEM is the lower part of the brain that connects to the spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the midbrain (mesencephalon) div: The midbrain (mesencephalon) is divided into the cerebral part and the upper part of the brainstem.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where is acetylcholine present in the CN: Acetylcholine is present in the CNS at the neuromuscular junction and in certain areas of the brain, such as the basal ganglia, septum, and cerebral cortex.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are each of the glutamate transpor: Each of the glutamate transporters is found in the plasma membrane.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How many muscarinic acetylcholine recept: There are three types of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, each coupled to different G proteins.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are GABAa receptors like ?: GABAa receptors are anionic, meaning they are negatively charged. They are also ligand-gated ion channels, which are a type of protein that forms a channel across a cell membrane and allows the passage of ions in response to a ligand binding to the receptor.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the glutamine cycle ?: The glutamine cycle refers to the process by which ammonia is removed from the body by being converted into glutamine, which is then excreted.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the course for axons in the cort: The corticospinal pathway is a set of white matter tracts that connect the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord. Axons in this pathway originate in the cortex and travel down the spinal cord to innervate muscles and other structures in the body.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are AMPA receptors important for ?: AMPA receptors are important for fast synaptic transmission.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens when the basilar membrane m: When the basilar membrane moves downwards, it causes the amplitude of vibration to increase.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are muscle spindles ?: Muscle spindles are sensory receptors located within the belly of a muscle that primarily detect changes in the length of the muscle.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what are spontaneous active bursting neu: Spontaneous active bursting neurons are neurons that exhibit spontaneous rhythmic bursting activity in the absence of any external stimuli.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is conductive hearing loss ?: Conductive hearing loss is a type of hearing loss that occurs when there is a problem with the mechanical part of the ear, which includes the eardrum and the three small bones in the middle ear. This can be due to various factors such as earwax blockage, fluid in the middle ear, or damage to the eardrum or the bones.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which cranial nerve exits on the dorsal: The cranial nerve that exits on the dorsal surface is the Trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV).
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is asteroagnosia ?: Asteroagnosia is the inability to perceive the passage of time.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is temporal summation ?: Temporal summation refers to the process where repeated stimuli are presented in quick succession, leading to a larger response than if the stimuli were presented individually. This phenomenon is due to the temporal integration of the stimuli, which enhances the overall effect.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the purpose of gephyrin in the g: Gephyrin is a protein that helps to cluster glycine receptors together in the postsynaptic membrane.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How does botulinium work ?: Botulinium works by inhibiting the release of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that is responsible for transmitting signals across nerve endings.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Why is dysnergia ?: Dysnergia is a condition characterized by the inability to perform rapid, coordinated movements. This can be due to a variety of factors, including muscle weakness, lack of coordination, or problems with motor control. The condition is often seen in neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease or stroke, where there is damage to the brain regions responsible for coordinating movement.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the 3 inputs to lower motor neu: The 3 inputs to lower motor neurons are from the cerebellum, red nucleus, and basal ganglia.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which nuclei share the embryo logical or: The nuclei that share the embryological origin with the nuclei of the somatic efferent cell column are the nuclei of the motor neurons.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How many amino acids make up the D1 rece: The D1 receptor is made up of 477 amino acids.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What does the midbrain locomotor area do: The midbrain locomotor area is responsible for the coordination of voluntary movements.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the pathways important in contr: The pathways important in controlling the trunk are the anterior and posterior gray rami of the spinal nerves.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is saltatory conduction ?: Saltatory conduction refers to the process of nerve impulse conduction along myelinated nerve fibers, where the action potentials 'hop' from one node of Ranvier to the next, allowing for faster transmission of the signal.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are kainate receptors thought to be: Kainate receptors are thought to be involved in synaptic plasticity.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Give examples of neurodegenerative disor: Neurodegenerative disorders are characterized by the progressive degeneration of the structure and function of the nervous system. Examples of such disorders include Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Describe progressive supranuclear palsy: Progressive supranuclear palsy is a rare brain disorder that causes serious problems with walking, balance and eye movements. People with this condition often have a progressive decline in balance and coordination, leading to difficulties with walking and frequent falls. They may also experience changes in speech and swallowing, as well as problems with eye movements that can cause difficulty in looking downward.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What type of receptor is 5-HT3 ?: 5-HT3 is a type of receptor known as a ligand-gated ion channel.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are the cell bodies of sympathetic: The cell bodies of sympathetic preganglionic neurones are located in the thoracic and lumbar regions of the spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the pons ?: The pons is part of the brainstem and it helps to relay messages between the brain and the spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What activates class 1 and 2 metabotropi: Class 1 and 2 metabotropic glutamate receptors are activated by the neurotransmitter glutamate.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Why is an action potential normally unid: An action potential is normally unidirectional because it is an all-or-none phenomenon. Once the threshold potential is reached, the membrane potential rapidly changes to a positive value and then returns to the resting potential. This change in membrane potential occurs in one direction and does not reverse spontaneously.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How are the motor systems organised ?: The motor systems are organised into functional blocks known as motor units.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the mesocortical pathway ?: The mesocortical pathway is a part of the limbic system that connects the amygdala to the prefrontal cortex. It plays a role in regulating emotions and is involved in the stress response.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the 3 ascending pain pathways ?: The 3 ascending pain pathways are the spinothalamic tract, the spinocerebellar tract, and the gracile fasciculus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the examples of endogenous liga: Endogenous ligands of cannabis include 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2-AG) and anandamide.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the causes of hypoventilation ?: The causes of hypoventilation include central nervous system disorders, peripheral nervous system disorders, and disorders of the respiratory system.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens if you damage peripheral or: Damage to peripheral components of the somatosensory system results in loss of specific sensations in the corresponding area of the body, while damage to central components can lead to a loss of all sensations from the affected area.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What transporter is used to store acetyl: The vesicular acetylcholine transporter (VAChT) is used to store acetylcholine.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where is there higher sensitivity for sw: The tip of the tongue is more sensitive to sweet taste than other parts of the tongue.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are GABAb receptors like ?: GABAb receptors are G protein-coupled receptors.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the 4 BRAINSTEM motor pathways: The 4 BRAINSTEM motor pathways are: 1. Pyramidal tracts (Corticospinal tracts) 2. Extra pyramidal tracts (Extracortical tracts) 3. Reticular formation 4. Medial longitudinal fasciculus
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens when the basilar membrane m: When the basilar membrane moves upward, it causes the amplitude of vibration of the outer hair cells to increase.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are spontaneous active bursting neu: Spontaneous active bursting neurones are neurons that exhibit spontaneous rhythmic activity without the need for external stimuli. These neurons are capable of generating and sustaining rhythmic action potentials, which can be crucial in various physiological processes such as pacemaker cells in the heart or neurons in the brain that regulate sleep-wake cycles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are depolarising activated inactiva: Depolarising activated inactivating potassium channels are found in skeletal muscle.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the Golgi tendon organ ?: The Golgi tendon organ is a proprioceptive sensory receptor organ that is located at the junction of a muscle and its tendon.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What was PD first described as ?: PD was first described as a deficiency of dopamine.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where does the hypoglossal nerve arise f: The hypoglossal nerve arises from the medulla oblongata.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the internal capsule ?: The internal capsule is a collection of nerve fibers that connect the cerebral cortex to the brainstem.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are alpha-7 acetylcholine receptor: Alpha-7 acetylcholine receptors are present in the brain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are dermatomes ?: Dermatomes are regions of the skin that are innervated by a single spinal nerve or a single cranial nerve.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens to glutamate after its rele: Glutamate is taken up by surrounding neurons and astrocytes.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the middle level of sensory feed: The middle level of sensory feedback to the motor hierarchy is the Proprioceptive level.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the spinal meninges ?: The spinal meninges are the protective coverings of the spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What controls the release of hormones fr: The release of hormones from the pituitary gland is controlled by the hypothalamus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Define dementia:: Dementia is a syndrome characterized by a decline in memory, language skills, understanding, and the ability to recognize and respond to the environment.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where is language specialisation mainly: Language specialisation is mainly in the left hemisphere of the brain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.If dopaminergic systems are damaged diff: When dopaminergic systems are damaged, several disorders can occur. The substantia nigra is a region of the brain that is primarily involved in the production of dopamine, which is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in the basal ganglia, a group of nuclei in the brain that are involved in motor control and other functions.  When there is damage to the dopaminergic system, the most common disorder that occurs is Parkinson's disease. This is because the substantia nigra is responsible for producing dopamine, and when there is a loss of dopamine-producing cells in the substantia nigra, it leads to the characteristic symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia (slowness of movement).  The ventral tegmental area (VTA) is another region of the brain that is involved in the production of dopamine. The VTA projects to the striatum, which includes the caudate nucleus and putamen. The striatum is also part of the basal ganglia and is involved in motor control and other functions.  When there is damage to the dopaminergic system, the VTA can also be affected, leading to a decrease in dopamine levels in the striatum. This can result in
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What acts as an agonist at muscarinic ac: Acetylcholine acts as an agonist at muscarinic acetylcholine receptors.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How is GABA broken down ?: GABA is broken down by GABA transaminase.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the vermis ?: The vermis is a part of the cerebellum.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the molecule involved in vesicl: The molecule involved in vesicles release is called SNARE. SNARE proteins are a family of membrane proteins that are essential for the fusion of vesicles with the cell membrane. They are found in various organisms, including humans, and play a crucial role in the transport of materials within and between cells. SNARE proteins function by forming a tight bond between the vesicle membrane and the cell membrane, allowing the contents of the vesicle to be released into the cell or the extracellular space. This process is vital for many cellular functions, including exocytosis, endocytosis, and the release of neurotransmitters at the synapse.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What does photopic mean ?: Photopic refers to vision under bright light conditions.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is a major part of the outer ear ?: The outer ear consists of the pinna and the auditory canal.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the visual system specialised to: The visual system is specialised to detect edges.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the midbrain important for and w: The midbrain is important for motor control and vision. During development, the alar part of the midbrain reduces in size.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How is glycine synthesised ?: Glycine is synthesised from serine and choline.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What does vesamicol do to cholinergic tr: Vesamicol inhibits cholinergic transmission by blocking the presynaptic release of acetylcholine (ACh).
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.When are peptides referred to as neuromo: Peptides are referred to as neuromodulators when they are used to send signals between neurons or from neurons to muscles, endocrine glands, or other effector cells.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the cerebellum ?: The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating voluntary movements, maintaining balance, and ensuring smooth and precise motor control.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is ocular dominance ?: Ocular dominance refers to the eye that is dominant or more strongly represented in the visual cortex. Typically, the right eye is considered dominant in most individuals.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.In knocked out mice where are the m4 rec: In knocked out mice, the m4 receptors are expressed in the striatum. The function of these receptors is to mediate the action of acetylcholine in the striatum, which is involved in motor control and coordination.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.From rat spinal cord what is the structu: Glycine receptors from rat spinal cord are pentameric ligand-gated ion channels.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.In the CNS why are action potentials gen: Action potentials are generally generated in the axon initial segment of neurons in the CNS because this region has the lowest threshold for excitation. This is due to a higher density of voltage-gated sodium channels in the axon initial segment compared to other parts of the neuron. As a result, when a stimulus is applied, it is more likely to depolarize the axon initial segment and initiate an action potential.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Describe fast motor units: Fast motor units are characterized by their high threshold for activation, meaning they require a stronger stimulus to contract. They also have a relatively short contraction time and high resistance to fatigue, making them suitable for powerful, quick actions.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what happens to movements when the indir: Activation of the indirect pathway in the basal ganglia leads to an increase in movement.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are intrafusal muscle fibres ?: Intrafusal fibres are found in the muscle spindle, which is a proprioceptive sensory receptor organ within the belly of a muscle that primarily senses changes in the length of the muscle.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the dopamine receptors ?: The dopamine receptors are a group of G protein-coupled receptors that are activated by the neurotransmitter dopamine.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are m4a acetylcholine receptors ex: M4a acetylcholine receptors are expressed in the striatum.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are high frequency sounds heard on: High frequency sounds are heard on the basilar membrane near the oval window.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is an antagonist of NMDA receptors: An antagonist of NMDA receptors is Amantadine.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the basal gangli: The basal ganglia are involved in the planning and programming of voluntary movements.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What do rods and cones look like ?: Rods and cones are the two types of photoreceptor cells in the retina. Rods are slender, cylindrical cells that are about 3 micrometers long and have an outer segment that is about 0.2 micrometers in diameter. Cones, on the other hand, are somewhat conical in shape and are about 6 micrometers long with an outer segment that is about 0.5 micrometers in diameter.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Explain the autonomic nervous system: The autonomic nervous system is a part of the peripheral nervous system that regulates involuntary body functions. It is responsible for maintaining homeostasis and includes two divisions: the sympathetic division, which prepares the body for 'fight or flight' responses, and the parasympathetic division, which promotes'rest and digest' activities.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the properties of group 1(a-alp: Group 1(a-alpha) afferents are associated with pain and temperature.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are accommodating neurones ?: Accommodating neurones are a type of neuron that can change their shape to fit the amount of information they need to process. They are found in the cerebellum and are responsible for coordinating movement and maintaining balance.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens to the dorsal column pathwa: At the medulla, the dorsal column pathways undergo a change in name and function. They are no longer responsible for conveying fine touch, vibration sense, and proprioception, which are now handled by the anterolateral pathways. Instead, the dorsal column pathways at the medulla become involved in the conduction of motor information, playing a role in the reflex arc.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what happens when the otolithic membrane: When the otolithic membrane moves, it causes the cupula to move.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what is the macula ?: The macula is a small part of the retina that is responsible for central vision and sharp focus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.explain meissner\u2019s corpuscles?: Meissner's corpuscles are specialized tactile receptors located in the nonhairy parts of the skin. They are most densely packed in the fingertips, lips, and other areas that require high sensitivity to touch. These structures are encapsulated nerve endings that are highly sensitive to light touch, allowing for the detection of fine details and texture.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How many endings of first order neurons: The glomerulus receives endings of first order neurons from 10 to 20 % of the olfactory bulb.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the trigeminal system ?: The trigeminal system is a part of the central nervous system.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what are phased neurons ?: Phased neurons are neurons that have a rhythmic discharge pattern.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the structure of the glycine rec: The glycine receptor is a ligand-gated chloride channel.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the uncus ?: The uncus is a part of the brain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is syringomyelia ?: Syringomyelia is a condition characterized by the formation of a fluid-filled cavity, or syrinx, within the spinal cord. This cavity can expand over time and may lead to the destruction of the spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the cerebral peduncles?: The cerebral peduncles are part of the midbrain, which is a structure located in the brainstem. They are connected to the diencephalon and the pons.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the olfactory bu: The olfactory bulb is responsible for processing sensory information from the olfactory system, which is involved in the sense of smell.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the reverse stretch reflex ?: The reverse stretch reflex is also known as the inverse stretch reflex.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Explain the dorsal paraventricular pathw: The dorsal paraventricular pathway is a neural circuit that originates in the dorsolateral part of the caudal ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus. It projects to the nucleus of the solitary tract in the medulla oblongata and the nucleus ambiguus in the medulla. This pathway is involved in the regulation of cardiovascular and respiratory functions.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which mechanoreceptors are characteristi: Pacinian corpuscles are characteristic of discrete receptive fields of the hand, while free nerve endings have more broad receptive zones.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What balance/postural impairments occur: In Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP), balance and postural control are significantly affected. Patients typically exhibit a wide-based, unsteady gait and difficulty with balance when standing or walking. This can lead to frequent falls. Additionally, there is a characteristic retropulsion where patients are pushed forward when attempting to stand from a sitting position.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is another name for ionotropic acet: Ionotropic acetylcholine receptors are also known as Nm receptors.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the 4 classes of somatosensory: The 4 classes of somatosensory receptors are free nerve endings, encapsulated nerve endings, organ of Corti, and muscle spindles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what acceleration is detected by the oto: The otolith organs and the semicircular canals detect linear and angular acceleration respectively.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the visceral motor nuclei found: The visceral motor nuclei in the brainstem are the GSE, GVE, and GVi nuclei.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where is dopamine within neurons ?: Within neurons, dopamine is found in the synaptic cleft.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.If you get an inward positive current wh: If you get an inward positive current, it means that there are more positive ions entering the cell than leaving it. This results in depolarization, where the membrane potential becomes more positive. Therefore, the postsynaptic potential would become more positive as well.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the corona radiata ?: The corona radiata is a structure in the brain consisting of nerve fibers that originate from the cerebral cortex and extend outward to various parts of the brain and spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are axo-axonic synapses ?: Axo-axonic synapses are connections between the axon of one neuron and the axon of another neuron.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Why is the red nucleus highly pigmented: The red nucleus is highly pigmented because it contains a high concentration of cytochrome c, which is an enzyme that plays a role in cellular respiration and energy production.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the receptors and affinities of: Tachykinin receptors are of two types: NK1 and NK2. Substance P, which is a tachykinin peptide, has a high affinity for the NK1 receptor.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are axo-somatic synapses ?: Axo-somatic synapses are connections between the axon of one neuron and the cell body (soma) of another neuron.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the reticular nucleus important: The reticular nucleus is important for the regulation of muscle tone.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What 3 types of cells are present in the: The 3 types of cells present in the glutamine cycle are Amoeba, Paramecium, and Euglena.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the main functions of the spina: The spinal cord is responsible for transmitting motor commands from the brain to the muscles, as well as processing reflexes within the spinal cord itself.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the 2 components of the oculomo: The oculomotor nerve is composed of 2 components: the parasympathetic root and the somatic root.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens when light hits the cornea: When light hits the cornea and refracts, it slows down.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What information from the retina is proc: The right LGN processes information from the left retina, while the left LGN processes information from the right retina.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where is laminae 7 situated and what is: Laminae 7 is situated in the occipital lobe and is called the primary visual cortex.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is fenfluramine used for and why ?: Fenfluramine is used as an appetite suppressant. It is part of a combination drug known as fenfluramine-phentermine, which was previously used for the treatment of obesity. However, it has been withdrawn from the market due to serious cardiovascular side effects.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the slowly activity cutaneous m: The slowly activity cutaneous mechanoreceptors are known as the Ruffini corpuscles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the glycine receptor involved in: The glycine receptor is involved in inhibitory synapses.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the difference between threshold: Lipid-soluble odorants have a lower threshold value compared to water-soluble odorants.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the middle level of the central: The middle level of the central motor system is the Reticular formation.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are metabotropic receptors ?: Metabotropic receptors are a class of G protein-coupled receptors that play a crucial role in cellular signaling. They are called'metabotropic' because they are involved in the metabolism of the cell, leading to changes in ion channel activity, gene expression, and cellular contraction. These receptors are found in various tissues throughout the body and are involved in the regulation of numerous physiological processes.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What receptors detect chemicals ?: Receptors for chemical substances are found in the plasma membrane of cells.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.where are the hair cells in the semicirc: The hair cells are located in the ampullated ends of the semicircular canals.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Describe 5-HT 1 receptors ?: 5-HT 1 receptors are found in the brain and are associated with the contraction of smooth muscles, including those in the blood vessels, gut, and airways. They also play a role in thermoregulation and the sleep-wake cycle. These receptors are sensitive to the hormone serotonin and can be activated by certain medications such as triptans, which are used to treat migraines.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the theories of mechanotransduc: The theories of mechanotransduction include the tensional homeostasis theory, the liquid crystal theory, and the piezoelectric theory.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which structure is more rostral - optic: The optic chiasm is more rostral than the mammillary bodies.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How is acetylcholine inactivated in the: Acetylcholine is inactivated in the synaptic cleft by enzymatic breakdown by acetylcholinesterase.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Examples of referred pain?: Referred pain is a phenomenon where pain is perceived in a different location from where it originates. This can occur due to the sharing of nerve pathways between different body parts. Some common examples of referred pain include:  1. Shoulder pain: Pain originating in the neck can be perceived in the shoulder region due to the shared nerve supply between the neck and shoulder. 2. Toothache: Pain from a toothache can be felt in the ear due to the shared nerve supply between the teeth and the ear. 3. Kidney stones: Pain from kidney stones can be felt in the back due to the shared nerve supply between the kidneys and the back. 4. Heart attack: Pain from a heart attack can be felt in the left arm or jaw due to the shared nerve supply between the heart and these areas. 5. Shingles: Pain from shingles can be felt in areas other than the affected skin, such as the back or chest, due to the shared nerve supply.  Remember that referred pain is not real pain, but rather a misinterpretation of pain by the brain. It is important to consult a healthcare professional for accurate diagnosis and treatment.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the overall function of the ocul: The oculomotor nucleus is responsible for coordinating the movements of the eyeball and the muscles that control the eyelids.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the main receptor groups of olf: The main receptor groups of olfactory receptors are located in the olfactory epithelium.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is dysmetria ?: Dysmetria is a neurological disorder characterized by the inability to accurately gauge distances, which can lead to problems with coordination and precision during movements.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Explain bilingualism ?: Bilingualism is the ability to use two languages fluently and with equal facility.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where does decussation occur in the asce: Decussation in the ascending auditory pathway occurs at the level of the superior olivary nucleus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are the cell bodies of the parasym: The cell bodies of the parasympathetic preganglionic neurons are located in the intermediolateral gray column of the spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What subunits for nAChR are present in t: The subunits for nAChR present in the brain are α4 and β2.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the cerebellum critical for?: The cerebellum is critical for coordinating voluntary movements.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens when glutamate binds to mGl: Glutamate binding to mGluR2 receptors leads to the activation of G-protein coupled inwardly-rectifying potassium channels, which results in hyperpolarization of the neuron.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the functions of the hypoglossa: The hypoglossal nerve is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of the tongue. It also carries sensory information from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the colour opponencies you can: The colour opponencies you can have are red-green, blue-yellow, and purple-orange.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is hypogeusia and ageusia ?: Hypogeusia and ageusia are conditions related to the sense of taste. Hypogeusia refers to a decreased ability to taste certain substances, while ageusia is the complete loss of the sense of taste. These conditions can be caused by various factors such as neurological disorders, certain medications, or underlying health issues.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are some of the causes of shunted b: Shunted blood can be caused by conditions such as arteriovenous malformation (AVM), arteriovenous fistula (AVF), and portal hypertension.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Define: neuromodulator: A neuromodulator is a substance that modulates the transmission of information in the nervous system.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What receptors detect cold ?: Cold receptors are called Ruffini corpuscles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How is glutamate released from the nerve: Glutamate is released from the nerve terminal by exocytosis.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the causes of subdural haemotom: The causes of subdural haemotoma include head trauma, coagulopathy, cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, and cerebral neoplasms.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the 3 cortical pathways ?: The 3 cortical pathways are: 1. Dorsolateral pathway 2. Ventral pathway 3. Medial pathway
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the olfactory ne: The olfactory nerve is responsible for the sense of smell.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the corticospina: The corticospinal tract is responsible for carrying motor information from the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the sequence of events in the o: The sequence of events in the olfaction cascade is as follows: 1. Odorant molecules bind to receptors in the olfactory epithelium. 2. This binding activates G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). 3. The activated GPCRs stimulate adenylyl cyclase (AC) via a Gs protein. 4. Adenylyl cyclase catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP). 5. Cyclic AMP then activates protein kinase A (PKA). 6. Protein kinase A phosphorylates ion channels, leading to the opening of sodium channels. 7. Sodium ions enter the cell, causing depolarization. 8. The depolarization triggers the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels. 9. Calcium ions enter the cell, further contributing to the depolarization. 10. The combined effect of sodium and calcium entry leads to the generation of an action potential. 11. The action potential propagates along the olfactory sensory neurons to the olfactory bulb. 12. In the olfactory bulb, the action potentials are processed and interpreted as different odors.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.When does the diffusion limit become lar: The diffusion limit becomes larger when the Reynolds number is less than 2000.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are some of the key areas of the su: Some key areas of the subdivisions of the cerebral cortex include the primary motor cortex, which is responsible for planning and executing voluntary movements; the primary sensory cortex, which processes sensory information; and the association cortex, which is involved in higher-level cognitive functions such as language, memory, and perception.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What enzyme converts the prepropeptide i: The enzyme that converts the prepropeptide into the propeptide is called the signal peptidase.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the functions if the glossophar: The glossopharyngeal nerve has several functions, including the taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue, the sense of smell, and the regulation of the carotid sinus and aortic arch.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the physiological roles of vaso: Vasopressin is a hormone that plays several important roles in the body. It is primarily involved in regulating water balance by acting on the kidneys to reduce urine output and increasing water reabsorption. Additionally, vasopressin has roles in the cardiovascular system, where it helps to increase blood pressure and constrict blood vessels. It also has a part in the central nervous system, where it is involved in the regulation of the stress response and the release of other hormones.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where is s2 and what does it do ?: s2 is located in the cytoplasm and it is involved in the formation of the contractile ring during cytokinesis.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How does info enter the limbic system ?: Info enters the limbic system through the thalamus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which glutamate receptors are more dense: NMDA receptors are more dense on the postsynaptic membrane, while AMPA receptors are more dense on the presynaptic membrane.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which nuclei share the embryo logical or: The nuclei that share the embryological origin- nuclei of the parasympathetic cell column are the dorsal nucleus of the vagus nerve and the nucleus ambiguus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What 2nd messenger system does glutamate: Glutamate class 1 receptors use the IP3 - DAG pathway as their 2nd messenger system.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are 2 examples of therapeutic dopam: 2 examples of therapeutic dopaminergic drugs are L-Dopa and Bromocriptine.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which tract originates in the red nucleu: The rubrospinal tract originates in the red nucleus and is involved in the regulation of muscle tone.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are m2 acetylcholine receptor?: m2 acetylcholine receptors are found in the heart.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the 3 modes in which peptides a: The 3 modes in which peptides are expressed in neurons are: 1. Classical neuropeptides, which are synthesized as preprohormones and processed to produce biologically active peptides. 2. Prohormones, which are precursors to hormones and are converted into their active forms within the neuron. 3. Neuromodulators, which are signaling molecules that modulate the activity of neurons and can be either classical neuropeptides or other types of molecules.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are examples of serotonin neurotoxi: Serotonin neurotoxins include substances like MPTP (1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine), which is used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease but can cause Parkinson-like symptoms when ingested in large amounts. Another example is 5,6-methylenedioxy-N-methylamphetamine (MDA), which is a drug of abuse that can cause damage to serotonin-containing neurons.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What does the mesoderm form around the n: The mesoderm forms around the neural tube as a pair of longitudinal folds called the paraxial mesoderm.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which cranial nerves enter/exit the midb: Cranial Nerve 3 (oculomotor nerve) and Cranial Nerve 4 (trochlear nerve) enter/exit the midbrain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the class 1 metabotropic recept: Class 1 metabotropic receptors are glutamate receptors that are coupled to G-proteins. They are involved in various functions such as regulating neuronal excitability, synaptic plasticity, and motor control.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is an antagonist of AMPA/kainate re: An antagonist of AMPA/kainate receptors is 6-cyano-7-nitroquinoxaline-2,3-dione (CNQX).

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) 5. Obesity 6. Sleep apnea 7. Smoking 8. Asthma 9. Postnasal drip 10. Allergic rhinitis 11. Nasal polyps 12. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency 13.
