Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome 26. Primary hyperparathyroidism 27. Medullary thyroid carcinoma 28. Parathyroid adenoma 29. Adrenal gland tumors 30. Hyperaldoster
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the purpose of the tonotopoc org: The tonotopoc organisation of the basilar membrane is designed to enhance the perception of sound.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the pathway for the stretch refl: The stretch reflex pathway involves afferent neurons that activate efferent neurons without synapsing in the CNS.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How are we able to see so many different: We are able to see so many different colours because of the way our eyes are structured and because of the way light behaves. Our eyes have special cells called cones and rods that are sensitive to different wavelengths of light, which is what gives us our perception of colour.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Examples of acute pain \u2026: Examples of acute pain include: 1. A child who has a sore throat 2. A person who has a toothache 3. A woman who has a sprained ankle 4. A man who has a severe headache 5. A dog that has been stung by a bee 6. A cat that has been cut by a sharp object 7. A bird that has a broken wing 8. A fish that has a damaged fin 9. A plant that has been injured by an animal 10. A rock that has been hit by another rock
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Explain zone 1 of the flow zones in an u: Zone 1 of the flow zones in an upright lung is characterized by a positive pleural pressure throughout the breathing cycle. This means that the pressure inside the lung is higher than the pressure outside the lung, which can make it difficult for air to enter the lung. As a result, there is little to no gas exchange occurring in this zone.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the pathological markers of pic: The pathological markers of picks disease are spongiosis and vacuolization of neurons.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens when glutamate binds to mGl: Glutamate binding to mGluR1 receptor leads to the activation of PLC, which in turn causes the mobilization of calcium from intracellular stores.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where does the substantia nigra project: The substantia nigra projects to the corpus striatum.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is another name for interventricula: The other name for interventricular foramen is Foramen of Monro.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is MRI imaging ?: MRI imaging stands for Magnetic Resonance Imaging. It is a medical imaging technique that uses a strong magnetic field and radio waves to create detailed images of the organs and tissues in the body.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How is glutamate stored into vesicles ?: Glutamate is stored into vesicles by being pumped out of the cytosol and into the vesicle by a H+ antiporter.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How many inputs from photoreceptors do b: Bipolar cells receive input from one or more photoreceptors.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is CT imaging ?: CT imaging stands for Computed Tomography imaging, which is a medical imaging technique that uses X-rays and computer technology to produce detailed cross-sectional images of the body.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What secretes CSF?: The choroid plexus secretes CSF (cerebrospinal fluid).
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens when dopamine binds to dopa: Binding of dopamine to dopamine D2 receptor leads to inhibition of adenylate cyclase.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is epilepsy.?: Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What activates class 3 metabotropic glut: Class 3 metabotropic glutamate receptors are activated by the neurotransmitter L-glutamate.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens to the eyes of a lesion or: When there is a lesion or damage to the trochlear nerve, the affected eye may exhibit an outward rolling or lateral strabismus, also known as trochlear nerve palsy.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is neglect syndrome ?: Neglect syndrome is a condition where a person ignores or fails to respond to stimuli on one side of their body, typically occurring after damage to the brain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the general structure and functi: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are pentameric ligand-gated ion channels composed of alpha and beta subunits. They are found in the postsynaptic membrane of neuromuscular junctions and at neuronal synapses. The receptors are named for their high affinity for the neurotransmitter acetylcholine, which binds to the alpha subunit. Binding of acetylcholine opens the channel, allowing sodium and potassium ions to flow in and out of the cell, thus transmitting the neural signal.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What makes up the roof of the 4th ventri: The roof of the 4th ventricle is made up of the inferior colliculi.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens if you have a unilateral sp: If you have a unilateral spinal cord injury, you lose sensation and motor control on the opposite side of the body from where the injury is located.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Why does the development of the cerebral: The development of the cerebral hemispheres forms a C shape due to the expansion of the lateral ventricles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Give examples of catecholamines: Catecholamines are a group of hormones that include adrenaline, noradrenaline, and dopamine. These hormones are derived from the amino acid tyrosine and are synthesized in the adrenal medulla and the brain. They play a crucial role in the body's fight-or-flight response and are involved in regulating heart rate, blood vessel constriction, and blood glucose levels.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Explain what happens in the signal trans: In the signal transduction in photoreceptors, the signal is transmitted from the G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) to the second messenger system.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Describe the ventral anterior nucleus of: The ventral anterior nucleus of the thalamic nuclei is concerned with motor function. It is part of the motor region of the thalamus, which also includes the ventral lateral nucleus and the oral nucleus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are pacinian corpuscles ?: Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings that are responsible for the sensation of touch. They are located in the skin, particularly in the dermal papillae, and are named after the Italian physician Giorgio Pacini who first described them. These corpuscles are encapsulated by concentric lamellae of connective tissue, which allows them to respond to pressure and vibration but not to pain or temperature.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the relationship between the dis: The distribution of blood flow through an upright human lung is not uniform; blood flow is actually greater in the base of the lung than at the apex.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which structures of the brain connect th: The cerebral hemispheres are connected by the corpus callosum, which consists of a large number of commissural fibers.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Why are taste buds not true neurons ?: Taste buds are not true neurons because they do not have the ability to generate action potentials. While they are specialized structures that detect taste, they lack the necessary components, such as a cell body and axon, to be considered neurons. Instead, they are classified as pseudostratified epithelial cells that send signals to the brain through sensory neurons.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what are tonic neurons?: Tonic neurons are neurons that maintain a constant level of activity over time, as opposed to phasic neurons which show bursts of activity followed by periods of inactivity.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the crossed extensor reflex ?: The crossed extensor reflex is a reflex that occurs when a stimulus is applied to the skin of one limb, causing the muscles of the opposite limb to contract and extend. This reflex is an example of a withdrawal reflex, which is a type of reflex that helps protect the body from potential harm by causing the affected part to move away from the stimulus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the abundance of glutamate and a: Glutamate and aspartate are abundant in the brain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens is the main purpose of the: The main purpose of the auditory receptors (hair cells) is to transduce sound energy into electrical energy.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Describe the MAO catabolism pathway for: The MAO catabolism pathway for dopamine involves the conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine by the enzyme monoamine oxidase (MAO). This reaction is part of the normal metabolic breakdown process for dopamine.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is equilibrium potential for an ion: The equilibrium potential for an ion is the membrane potential at which there is no net flow of the ion across the cell membrane.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is pyramidal decussation ?: Pyramidal decussation is a process in the brain where nerve fibers from one side of the brain cross over to the opposite side. This occurs in the medulla oblongata, which is part of the brainstem. It is important for coordinating movement and maintaining balance.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How are different frequency sounds heard: Different frequency sounds are heard through the basilar membrane of the cochlea.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What groups make up serotonin ?: Serotonin is made up of tryptophan, phenylalanine, and cysteine.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What pathway only terminates on motor ne: The cranial nerve pathway is the only one that exclusively terminates on motor neurons in humans and primates.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the causes of upper motor neuro: Upper motor neurone disease can be caused by a variety of factors, including stroke, motor neurone disease, and spinal cord injury. Each of these conditions can damage the nerve cells that control voluntary muscle movements, leading to the symptoms of upper motor neurone disease.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What arthe functions of the raphe nucleu: The raphe nucleus is responsible for the regulation of sleep-wake cycles, mood, and appetite.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the subthalamic nucleus importan: The subthalamic nucleus is important for the regulation of posture and equilibrium.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which lamina is part of the intermediate: The lamina of the intermediate horn is the lamina of the septum.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where is laminae 9 and what is it called: Laminae 9 is located in the occipital lobe and is also called the primary visual cortex.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is interaural time difference ?: The interaural time difference refers to the difference in the time it takes for sound to reach one ear compared to the other ear. This is an important cue for localizing sound sources in space.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How much more positive is the endolymph,: The endolymph,oh is approximately 140 times more positive than the perilymph.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is driving force equal to ?: The driving force is equal to the potential difference divided by the resistance.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What cerebellar peduncles connect the po: The cerebellar peduncles connect the pons to the cerebellum.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is an electrochemical potential ?: An electrochemical potential is the potential difference that exists between two electrodes of an electrochemical cell when it is in equilibrium.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are depolarising and calcium activa: Depolarising and calcium activated potassium channels are types of potassium channels.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Examples of chronic pain\u2026: Examples of chronic pain include low back pain, osteoarthritis, and headache.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where does the tectum lie ?: The tectum lies in the midbrain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is mild ad ?: Mild ad is a form of advertising that is not intrusive or aggressive, and it aims to build brand awareness and create a positive image for the product or service being promoted.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is ALS-PDC?: ALS-PDC is a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is Brodmann areas ?: Brodmann areas are a numerical system used to divide the cerebral cortex into different regions based on their cytoarchitectural characteristics, which are the structural features of the brain tissue.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the 3 receptors for glutamate ?: The 3 receptors for glutamate are NMDA, AMPA, and mGlu.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the general sensory nuclei foun: The general sensory nuclei in the BRAINSTEM include the mesencephalic nucleus of the 5th nerve, the nucleus of the 7th nerve, and the salivatory nucleus of the 9th nerve.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How is adrenaline made ?: Adrenaline is made from the amino acid tyrosine.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are the major clusters of choliner: The major clusters of cholinergic pathways in the CNS are located in the basal forebrain, brainstem, and cerebral cortex.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which receptors are activated by menthol: Menthol and capsaicin activate TRPM8 and TRPV1 receptors, respectively.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.After the release of serotonin what happ: Serotonin is taken back into the presynaptic neuron by a process called reuptake.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.If the membrane potential is at -90mV an: If the membrane potential is at -90mV and there is an inward current of sodium ions, the deflection of the epsc (excitatory postsynaptic current) will be positive, and the deflection of the epsp (excitatory postsynaptic potential) will also be positive.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How do the extraocular muscles of the ey: The extraocular muscles of the eye have fine control due to their innervation by the cranial nerves, which allow for precise and coordinated movement of the eye.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What fibres are associated with nocicept: Nociceptors are associated with A delta fibres.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the kinacillium ?: The kinacillium is the space between the eyelashes and the skin.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What does the middle ear do ?: The middle ear is an auditory organ that helps to transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the parietal lob: The parietal lobe is responsible for processing sensory information and helping to create our perception of the world around us.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where does layer 5 project to ?: Layer 5 projects to the Stratum Oralis.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are examples of inhibitory amino ac: Examples of inhibitory amino acid neurotransmitters include glycine and GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid).
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the hindbrain (rhombencephalon): The hindbrain (rhombencephalon) is divided into the medulla oblongata and the pons.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What areas do the Premotor areas directl: The Premotor areas directly control the Primary motor areas.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is current ?: Current is the amount of electric charge that flows through a circuit in one second.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Why are calculated reversal potentials a: The calculated reversal potentials are different to the real life reversal potentials because the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation, which is used to calculate them, does not take into account the activity of potassium channels.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the role of the potassium channe: Potassium channels play a crucial role in the action potential by allowing the efflux of potassium ions from the cell, which leads to hyperpolarization of the membrane. This hyperpolarization helps to bring the membrane potential back towards the resting level after an action potential has been generated.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the retinofugal projection ?: The retinofugal projection refers to the pathway of optic nerve fibers that project from the retina to the thalamus, specifically the lateral geniculate nucleus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the pathological markers of CBG: The pathological markers of CBGD include the presence of bile ductular proliferation, portal inflammation, and periportal fibrosis.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the largest part of the basal ga: The largest part of the basal ganglia is the Putamen.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How is serotonin stored ?: Serotonin is stored in the synaptic vesicles.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.In knocked out mice where are the m1 rec: In knocked out mice, the m1 receptors are expressed in the salivary glands. The function of these receptors is to stimulate saliva secretion.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are ion pumps ?: Ion pumps are proteins that move ions across cell membranes, using energy from ATP.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are m1 acetylcholine receptors pre: M1 acetylcholine receptors are present in the cerebral cortex.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What a Meissners corpuscles ?: Meissner's corpuscles are specialized tactile receptors located in the nonhairy parts of the skin, particularly abundant in the fingertips, lips, and other areas where tactile acuity is high. They are encapsulated nerve endings that are highly sensitive to touch, allowing for the detection of light touch and texture.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the earliest symptoms of ad ?: The earliest symptoms of Alzheimer's disease (AD) include forgetfulness and difficulty in finding words.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the falx cerebri ?: The falx cerebri is a large fold of dura mater that occupies the median longitudinal fissure between the two cerebral hemispheres.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the stimuli for olfaction ?: The stimuli for olfaction are molecules in the air.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the pigment in rods called and w: The pigment in rods is called Rhodopsin, and the 3 types of pigment in cones are Cyanolabe, Erythrolabe, and Chlorolabe.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens to off centre bipolar cells: When the centre of a bipolar cell or ganglion cell is dark, it indicates that there is little to no light reaching that area. In response, these cells reduce their activity. Off centre bipolar cells and ganglion cells are more active in the periphery when light is present, but they do not respond to light in their centre.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is vigabatrin used to treat ?: Vigabatrin is used to treat infantile spasms, which are a type of seizure seen in infants.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of cerebral aqueduc: The cerebral aqueduct is a narrow channel in the midbrain that connects the third and fourth ventricles of the brain, allowing cerebrospinal fluid to flow between these two cavities.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is wernickes aphasias ?: Wernicke's aphasia is a language disorder characterized by the inability to understand or interpret speech and language.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Describe the sensory transduction of tas: Taste receptor cells are sensory neurons that detect taste stimuli in the mouth and transmit signals to the brain. The sensory transduction process in these cells involves several steps. First, when a taste stimulus, such as a molecule from food, binds to the taste receptor protein on the cell membrane, it triggers a series of biochemical events. This leads to the opening of ion channels, specifically potassium channels, which allows potassium ions to flow out of the cell. The efflux of potassium ions causes the cell membrane potential to become more negative, leading to depolarization of the cell. This depolarization opens voltage-gated calcium channels, allowing calcium ions to enter the cell. The influx of calcium ions further contributes to the depolarization of the cell. If the depolarization reaches a threshold level, it triggers the release of neurotransmitters at the synapse with the next neuron, transmitting the taste signal to the brain. This process is known as the taste transduction cascade.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is Broca\u2019s aphasias ?: Broca’s aphasias is a language disorder characterized by difficulty in speech production.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What do the D2 receptors often act as ?: D2 receptors often act as presynaptic receptors.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What 2nd messenger system does norepinep: Norepinephrine uses the second messenger system of cyclic AMP (cAMP).
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the cranial nerves in order ?: The cranial nerves are in the following order: 1. Olfactory nerve 2. Optic nerve 3. Oculomotor nerve 4. Trochlear nerve 5. Trigeminal nerve 6. Abducens nerve 7. Facial nerve 8. Vestibulocochlear nerve 9. Glossopharyngeal nerve 10. Vagus nerve 11. Accessory nerve 12. Hypoglossal nerve
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the fasiculus cuneatus and fasic: The fasiculus cuneatus and fasiculus gracilis are bundles of nerve fibers that carry sensory information from the upper and lower body, respectively, to the brain.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What special sensory nuclei are found in: The special sensory nuclei found in the BRAINSTEM are the trigeminal sensory nucleus, the facial sensory nucleus, and the glossopharyngeal sensory nucleus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where are the cell bodies of parasympath: The cell bodies of parasympathetic post ganglionic neurons are found in the intermediolateral grey column of the spinal cord.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Choline is an essential nutrient, where: Choline is an essential nutrient that can be obtained from various food sources, including eggs, liver, and certain vegetables such as broccoli and Brussels sprouts.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are axo-dendritic synapses ?: Axo-dendritic synapses are connections between the axon of one neuron and the dendrites of another neuron.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the forebrain divided into ?: The forebrain is divided into the cerebrum and the diencephalon.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.what is the affective aggression pathway: The affective aggression pathway of serotonin involves the 5HT1A receptor.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is chemical transmission ?: Chemical transmission refers to the process by which information is transmitted between neurons through the use of chemical messengers called neurotransmitters.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.explain merkel\u2019s disks?: Merkel's disks, also known as Merkel's corpuscles, are specialized sensory receptors located in the skin. They are primarily found in areas of the body that experience frequent touch, such as the lips, fingertips, and sole of the foot. These receptors are responsible for detecting light touch and texture, allowing us to perceive sensations like pressure, vibration, and two-point discrimination.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the function of the post central: The post central gyrus is concerned with the processing of tactile sensations.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are extrafusal muscle fibres ?: Extrafusal muscle fibres refer to the muscle fibres that are located outside of the fusiform muscle layer. These fibres are responsible for generating force and are commonly found in the muscles of the limbs and the body wall.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is motor neurons disease ?: Motor neurons disease is a term used to describe a group of progressive neurological disorders that affect motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. These diseases, which include amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), progressive muscular atrophy (PMA), and primary lateral sclerosis (PLS), result in the degeneration of motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness, paralysis, and difficulty with speech, swallowing, and breathing.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.How many neurons are present in human ce: The human cerebral cortex contains approximately 16 billion neurons.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the functions of the vestibuloc: The vestibulocochlear nerve is responsible for balance and hearing.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What does split brain mean and what are: Split brain refers to the surgical separation of the two hemispheres of the brain, which can be done in cases of severe epilepsy. This procedure has several effects, including the loss of the corpus callosum, which is the bundle of nerves that connects the two hemispheres. As a result, the patient experiences hemispheric disconnection, meaning that the left and right hemispheres of the brain cannot communicate with each other. This can lead to various symptoms, including the inability to use both hands equally, difficulty with bimanual coordination, and challenges with certain cognitive functions that previously relied on interhemispheric communication.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are perceptual disparities perceive: Perceptual disparities are perceived as depth.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Where does the inferior colliculus recei: The inferior colliculus receives auditory information from the superior olivary nucleus and sends auditory information to the medial geniculate nucleus.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is referred pain ?: Referred pain is the phenomenon where pain is perceived in a location other than where the actual injury or damage is occurring.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What do the layers if the cerebral corte: The layers of the cerebral cortex are composed of different types of neurons that are arranged in a specific way. There are six layers in total, each with its own unique characteristics and functions. The neurons in these layers are involved in various processes such as receiving and transmitting information, processing sensory input, and coordinating motor output.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.explain the pyramidal tract/corticospina: The pyramidal tract, also known as the corticospinal tract, is a collection of nerve fibers that originate in the cerebral cortex and descend through the brainstem and spinal cord. It plays a crucial role in voluntary motor control, conveying messages from the brain to the spinal cord and then to the muscles. The majority of these fibers cross over at the level of the medulla oblongata, forming the pyramids of the medulla, hence the name 'pyramidal tract'. This crossover allows for the contralateral control of motor function, meaning that the left side of the brain controls the right side of the body, and vice versa. The pyramidal tract is essential for fine motor control and is involved in the execution of skilled movements.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the flow of connections of corti: The flow of connections of cortical areas is hierarchical.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the ready set go theory ?: The ready set go theory is a concept in child development that suggests infants are born with innate skills and abilities that develop in a relatively short period of time, typically within the first two years of life. This theory emphasizes the importance of environmental factors and interactions with caregivers in facilitating these developments. It proposes that infants are ready to learn and develop certain skills, such as language, motor skills, and social skills, once the necessary conditions and stimuli are provided. The theory highlights the role of sensitive and responsive caregiving in supporting infants' natural developmental progress.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Why are layers 2 and 3 of V1 very import: Layers 2 and 3 of V1 are very important because they are the primary sources of input to the middle temporal area (MT) and the superior temporal polysensory area (STP). These areas are involved in the processing of visual information.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What types of clinical uses does the EEG: The EEG has various clinical uses, including the diagnosis of epilepsy, sleep disorders, and brain death.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What are the causes of hydrocephalus ?: Hydrocephalus can be caused by a variety of factors, including genetic mutations, infections, and blockages in the brain's ventricular system.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which lies more laterally, fasiculus cun: Fasiculus cuneatus lies more laterally than fasiculus gracilis.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What happens to dopac and hva ?: When a neuron is depolarized, the sodium channels open and there is an influx of sodium ions into the cell. This influx of positive sodium ions causes the inside of the neuron to become more positive, leading to depolarization. As a result, the inside of the neuron becomes less negative compared to the outside. This change in membrane potential is what causes the action potential.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.Which electrodes in an EEG are positione: The electrodes positioned closest to the visual cortex in an EEG are the O1 and O2 electrodes.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What makes up the striatum ?: The striatum is made up of the caudate nucleus and putamen.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What pathways are important in controlli: The pathways that are important in controlling the distal musculature for fine movement are the corticospinal tracts and the rubrospinal tracts.
OpenBioLLM Llama3 8B_Doc Array In Memory.What is the link between serotonin and n: Serotonin is a neurohormone that plays a crucial role in regulating mood, sleep, and appetite. It is synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan and is primarily found in the gastrointestinal tract and the central nervous system. Serotonin acts as a neurotransmitter, mediating communication between nerve cells, and as a neurohormone, influencing various bodily functions. It is involved in the regulation of blood pressure, body temperature, and the secretion of hormones from the pituitary gland. Serotonin also has a role in the modulation of pain perception and is associated with feelings of well-being and happiness.
